Right now, the core step is needed. if it is disabled, the deployment won't work. After someone breaks it up into several steps, we can decide which ones of those are core and which are not. Hmm, does this mean that we will always have at least one core step; or will we just make all the steps 'always' or 'one-time' steps. Sigh.

I think we say a step only happens at most once (per clean or deploy), and you just get to choose the priority and arguments.

If you think about RAID, its kinda does two runs if you have a mix of mirrored and striped disks, but really that is just one run with complex config. Seems a good simplifying assumption.
I'm good with this. If needed, someone can make it more flexible it later :)

Overall, I like the idea of deployment steps and thank you for the spec.  I have a couple questions:  1) Does the deployment steps get executed after Nova scheduler selected a node?  Some deployment steps have hardware dependency, ex, RAID config will have dependency on the node with RAID controller.  If Nova selected a node that does not have the corresponding hardware capability, then the deploy step will fail.  2) Some deployment step may take a long time to complete and better to do it asynchronously.  One example is firmware update (although it might be better off to do it as a cleaning step).  Does the deployment framework allow one async deployment step to complete before executing another deployment step (similar to dependency requirement)?  For instance, firmware update to complete before OS deployment step.
Thanks!

Good questions Wan-yen.

Re 1) Yes, the deploy steps only happen *after* the nova-virt-ironic-driver issues the 'ironic-set-provision-state ACTIVE' request. I think it is up to the deploy step itself (in your case RAID config) to handle the case if it cannot do its job cuz of unavailable hardware or whatever. I suppose it could either not do anything (e.g. just skip me, use whatever RAID config is already there), or if the step thinks it is important, FAIL the entire deploy process.

Re 2) yes, the deploy steps/process will be similar to the clean step process. A step has to be finished before the next one is started.

Good question, I would say keep it the same.

But I think something we are missing here is in-band vs out-of-band. We want to define things such that we have a minimum number of reboot cycles.

Maybe that means we do: out-of-band, in-band then out-of-band as a kind of meta ordering that you must fit into?

Its not clear to me how that works with the clean steps today.

All the steps can have priorities assigned to them, so the order can be decided ahead of time. We just need to deal with the corner cases where two or more steps have the same priority (or raise an error and not do anything).

The out-of-band steps are usually in the power or management in
terfaces, and those two interfaces are done first (IF the steps have the same priority) so that would address your out-of-band before in-band. Really, on one should use the same priority for two steps; it is too confusing unless you know the algorithm.

Don't we also need to add some example optional deployment steps? Maybe we could do RAID?

Once we do that, it brings up the question of configuration. I guess you want to be able to change the default deploy and clean priority.

The default RAID configuration is on set on the Node in the API, but you probably want a default for when that is not set, and store that in config?

Oh. good question. I was only thinking about the framework/deploy steps. But yeah, clearly some people want RAID as a deploy step so I'll add that in as part of the spec. Hmm, but then, as you mention, what about the config. Isn't that what your deploy template spec addresses? Let me think about it.
Just thinking some kind of deploy_prepare state would be nice. would allow operators to better identify issues in their deploy process.

Good question. For this spec, I'd rather not have to add new states; that can be done later. Also, i am thinking/hoping that when we break up the existing deployment process into several deploy steps, it'll be clearer, when there are issues, at what point in the deployment, an issue occurred.

Interestingly, we don't include "priority" for manual clean steps, the order specified is used instead, which is way more friendly.
https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/cleaning.html#starting-manual-cleaning-via-api

Now quite how we resolve that with before/after core... and before/after any existing configured steps. Maybe we just require the core step to be included in the list, if deploy_steps are specified?

I think it'd be a burden to ask operators to specify the entire list of deploy steps that they want executed. But then you'll ask -- how is that different from manual cleaning? Well, cuz it is 'manual cleaning'. For automated cleaning, the operator doesn't specify anything via an API request.

That's what makes these deploy steps different. Another way would be to allow the operator to 'refer' (vs 'override') a 'core' or 'always' deploy step, to allow them to be able to easily specify the entire list of deploy steps to execute. but what if they miss one...
I think we should define the error cases here. The current deploy_step show which thing caused the deploy to go into an error step, just like with cleaning?
Yeah, whatever we do with cleaning, should be similar for deploy steps. (Just that I've forgotten what that was...)
I assume that is the same as manual clean? It seems sensible.
If i recall, the same except for the additional 'priority'. I'll look into it and update the spec.
Will this impact the deploy time_out setting? if so will we be able to set a timeout for each step? and would that setting be added to the overall deploy time out.
yup. should document this in the admin guide.

Might be worth saying the time_out setting may need to be adjusted, depending on what you do to the deploy steps?

Seems fine to keep the timeout the same.

That's a good question. I had to take a look to see how things work now. With cleaning and deployment, there is a periodic check that will put the  node in a FAIL state if the node is in a [CLEAN|DEPLOY]WAIT state and if the ramdisk has not heartbeated for CONF.[clean|deploy]_callback_timeout. 

So no, it shouldn't impact the deploy_callback_timeout config value, unless someone adds a deploy step that causes the ramdisk to work so hard that it cannot heartbeat for a long time...

The key here is that the timeout value is used to time out if there is no heartbeat, vs the total length of time to do *something* in the ramdisk.

git_review/tests/test_git_review.py.message:
It's not clear to me what that would demonstrate. The git commands being run by git-review invocation shouldn't alter the submodules, but *if* they altered them in the same ways as they alter the superrepo then we wouldn't detect that by comparing the original and final states, as git-review tries to reset to the original state after the test rebase is performed.

The goal of this test and the one after it are to confirm that git-review can once again push changes when a dirty submodule is present. If we want to devise checks for whether git-review alters the contents of submodules in some way, we could certainly try to do so, but that would be something we haven't previously asserted in the testsuite and should be represented by one or more separate tests.
We should assert the state of the submodule contents hasn't changed after running git review.

Fungi pointed out that this only makes sense when using the autostash feature and the test suite doesn't currently support that. We can probably get away with git doing the right thing here and if this continues to cause problems for submodule users we can investigate more robust testing.
We should assert the state of the submodule contents hasn't changed after running git review.

cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/n.message: Not implementing this method will cause the migrated volume end up with a file name different of its volume cinder entity id. Normally, the driver creates the file with the file name as volume-<volume_id>, now after migrating it is going to have the file name as the volume-<volume_name_id>, where name_id is the id of the temporary volume entity. Is it the expected behaviour ?

Yes that is correct.
The idea is for cinder volume manager to support both type of drivers:
- Those that implement the method will try to rename the volume to use the original old id. If they fail cinder-volume manager will proceed as if it wasn't implemented.  In this case _name_id doesn't need to be set.
- For those that don't implement the method cinder-volume manager will store the real volume's id in _name_id, so drivers will have to use it instead of the id.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Agreed, that is sounding like a promising approach.  I re-checked the spec, and it looks like we failed to anticipate this problem at the time.

If we're concerned about the amount of data in zk with tenant queues, we could forward the events by reference (ie, have a single master copy of the event in zk, and then the tenant queues (and even tenant-pipeline) could reference that, so their znodes could be completely empty and their names simply references to the master copy.  If we did that, we'd need to reference count or garbage collect.  I can think of some, but they're non-trivial enough that we'd want to make sure it's really worth it.

If, on the other hand, the number of znodes is more concerning than the amount of data, then forward-by-reference doesn't help.  I don't have any ideas there.

Can you elaborate on this?  Is there a case where all of them need to be locked simultaneously, or that we need to lock each one of these before we process it?

Actually, a mini doc on what locks exist and when they need to be locked would be nice.  Could just be a docstring in zk/locks.py.

It seems these should be able to operate independently, and they should be able to continue to operate even if a tenant is write-locked (we can continue to dispatch events to the tenant, it just shouldn't process them).  But that's not how the event dispatching works now.  We actually do a lot of processing of events before we forward them to each tenant-pipeline queue, including deciding whether we should forward them based on the current pipeline config and also we allow them to trigger tenant reconfigurations.  Particularly because we go from a global queue to a tenant-pipeline queue, we have to know what pipelines are in a tenant in order to forward events to it.  That means we can't forward events while that tenant is being reconfigured.

Unfortunately this means that when we reconfigure a tenant, we will stop all global processing, which means that almost immediately after starting a reconfiguration for one tenant, we will "stop the world" for all tenants.  Sure, we can still process results, but we're not likely to be starting many, if any, new jobs.

Tenant reconfiguration is an event in the global management queue.  If we only have one scheduler processing that at a time, then we could end up serializing reconfiguration events.  So if we take all of these together: the system will process one tenant reconfiguration event at a time, in sequence, and while reconfiguring each tenant, global event processing will stop, effectively stopping all activity.

That sounds remarkably like what we have today with a single scheduler.  Hopefully I'm missing something; otherwise we may need to rethink some of the event management.

Yes, with the way the global management and trigger event queues are currently implemented we can't continue processing the global event queues during a reconfiguration. I was aware of the issue with the serialized tenant reconfigurations, but did not think of the problem with forwarding trigger events.

When I brought up the issue of the the serialized reconfigs some time ago, IIRC we decided to follow the spec in this regard and stick with the global management/trigger event queues for now.

My proposal back then was to have tenant specific management/trigger event queues instead. The trade-off here would be that we need to duplicate all trigger events for each tenant.

> ... The trade-off here would be that we need to duplicate all trigger events for each tenant.

Of course, we can decide which events need to be forwarded to which tenant based on the tenant configuration. This way we are only duplicating events for projects that are part of multiple tenants.

Why would we need to acquire multiple locks?

In order to give the scheduler a chance to get a lock for reconfiguration I'm planning to re-lock the tenant before locking a pipeline. So basically something like:

    with locked(tenant_read_lock, pipeline_lock, blocking=False):
        ... process pipeline ...

However, I'm not using that in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/796013/1/zuul/scheduler.py in favor of better logging in case a tenant or pipeline is already locked.

I'm fine with removing the support for multiple locks.

If there were a tenant named "management" we would have a collision with the management lock above (it may not be a critical error, but it would at least be confusing).  How about we make this /zuul/locks/events/trigger/{safe_tenant} ?

There are 2 branches, so 2 spec files. On f/centos8 this file you are modifying will be used. On master a very similar file will be used, but with one difference: python-lxml instead of python3-lxml.

For building purposes: depends on which branch is checked out out for each git repo. (repo init to some branch). It will 'compile'(build) and package the source code differently: using python-lxml on master branch, using python3-lxml on f/centos8 branch.

doc/source/listyaml/listyaml.rst.message:
So appologies for the confusion.  I'll explain this as if I were speaking to the organization.  I'll note in the history of the project, RDO was defined as an installer, but it's not any more.

1. refer to upstream as TripleO
2. RDO is a set of packages / repos that enables OpenStack to be installed.  Installed by hand, puppet, packstack or TripleO
3. downstream of TripleO is OSP

There are only two installers that have community/official support and that's TripleO and OSP.

It's a good point that --installer tripleo could be confused with delinating components e.g tripleo component vs. glance component.  However in this context of "--installer" and not "--component" using tripleo still is more appropriate than rdo.  RDO is not an installer.  https://www.rdoproject.org/

What do you mean by an image `who were originally stored in ceph`?

When using the rbd imagebackend with the libvirt virt driver you can't move images to a new store within Glance as the ephemeral disks Nova creates directly reference the images as parents/backing stores. Moving these to swift or file would break that chain within RBD itself and render the disks useless.

You would need to flatten any existing ephemeral disks first before moving the images in Glance and at that point any request to directly snapshot the disks would fail and we would fallback to the offline snapshot and upload via g-api workflow.

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message: So I was just looking at this and I can't help but wonder if this should also be changed, albeit unrelated, to remove an entry from the cache if present. Just to keep things tidy (Yes, this would be a separate patch), and if the super inefficient "give me a number of nodes" call is ever refactored to use the cache, then it would be hyper-important to keep the cache tidy since the hash ring can change based upon participants to the hash ring.
Does it matter that this association may now be stale? The node may have had an instance_uuid set at the time we queried it, but no longer does, or vice versa.

node1 is managed by a compute named C1 on the hash ring before it was even scheduled. When it is scheduled node1 is deployed by  compute C1. Once this happens C1 always manages that instance for the life time of that instance.

> the nova instance list includes instance1, but because the node we got from the API has instance_uuid = None, we do not add it to the cache (assuming it does not hash to this service)

I thought we always use objects.InstanceList.get_by_host_and_node to figure out which instances are managed by this compute. If C1 manages node1 and instance_uuid is not set, it won't just abandon that node. objects.InstanceList.get_by_host_and_node should still return the instance uuid and show C1 that the node1 is still managed by it.

We have not seen any problems when node.instance_uuid is unset but it is stale. node.instance_uuid will be unset only after deletion of the instance. It may take some time for that node to be managed by the "right" compute service. Since we do cleaning on deletion of that instance, there is normally enough time for all compute services to reconcile with where the newly available node will land.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message: In thinking about it, there is really no explicit requirement that the instance_uuid is owned by only one nova deployment, and this would just result in any internal cache entry to be dropped. At least, that is my perception. Line 788 would just result in the baremetal node being completely ignored until the next pass-through, which I suspect is fine and was realistically already the case in that usage pattern. In a more run of the mill pattern, as Arun indicates, it should just get picked up on the next pass which *should* actually be better. It is also worth noting that since the node instance_uuid data is from an API query, which may have been removed on a task but not yet committed to the database, instances may already occur where nodes are ignored/removed from the cache pending the next run. However, afaik, that has never been reported as an issue since the node is in cleaning and other processes ignore the node by provision_state elsewhere if memory serves.

Here's the scenario I'm imagining.

* node list returns node1 with instance_uuid = None
* the API query takes a long time, during which instance1 is created and scheduled to node1
* the nova instance list includes instance1, but because the node we got from the API has instance_uuid = None, we do not add it to the cache (assuming it does not hash to this service)
* other compute services will remove the node from their cache on subsequent refreshes, since they see instance_uuid set
* the node is now not in any cache, which I believe is the bug we are trying to avoid

Ultimately, we've got two async queries which are potentially made many seconds apart, and I'm not sure how changing their order results in them being more synchronised.

I think these both should move to another configuration file section, maybe [controller_worker]. The ability to specify TLS ciphers is not an "amphora" or "haproxy" specific feature. Multiple Octavia drivers will likely support the ability to specify the cipher suites.
Let's try to make this more generic and not reference haproxy.

So, these both concern me slightly, because they expose very clearly things about our backend (that it is using HAProxy). Even if this is a somewhat common option/format, would it be better to keep it slightly more generic rather than copying the HAProxy variable name directly and referring to it in the docstring? Or did we decide to drop the illusion that we'll ever have any other amphora drivers besides HAProxy?
We set default_listener_ciphers and default_pool_ciphers in the same way, see line 108, 112.

So I finally figured out why this isn't showing up in the release notes, the first line after a heading should be:

  - |

I guess without that it's ignored.

So I think my previous comments were wrong on this file, since it still doesn't show up in the release note build.  But this time I have an answer - the file name needs to end in .yaml, not .yml.  If you simply make that change and leave everything else alone it will show up, verified by running 'tox -e releasenotes' and looking in the resultant releasenotes/build/html/unreleased.html file.

side question: in some files, we use amphora_client with the admin role, and in other files we use the lb_admin role, any reasons for that?

There are a number of places we create another client instead of using the list setup in base.
These all should be cleaned up in the future.

os_admin is the tempest credential setup with the admin role and system scope.
lb_admin is a credential we create, using the load-balancer_admin role, which is a service specific admin role in Octavia[1]. It is part of advanced RBAC.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/configuration/policy.html#term-role-load-balancer_admin
